pros: The pay is good, much better then other places. You will be given at least 1-2 raises per year. You may be afraid of the customers, the Karen's, but the customers are the best part of the job. Think of it this way, they'll always be a horrible customer, but how many amazing ones will there be? At Starbucks the regulars are the best, tip great and are the best people. If the right one comes, you'll make great friendships. They are unbelievable strict, but I see that as a good thing because its the same standard for everyone and drinks should always be the same. A ton of free coffee, and feeds my coffee fancy drink addiction. DOES NOT DISCRIMINATE, has the must inclusive community working with people that RESPECT eachothers religions, race, gender and sexuality.
cons: FAVOURTISM, the shifts can never do anything. Do not bring concerns about your issues to the manager, especially about the shifts, because the manager will always be best friends with them. The only way to make it anywhere in Starbucks, is to have everyone you work with (in position of power) like you. It's so toxic, towards its workers. I mean it when the customer ALWAYS NEEDS to be right. Even if they're in the wrong, you need to make them good. You get talked down to from those that are older, there's a major superiority complex and never help them. There's no place to grow, there's barely ever Amy opportunities, and once again its always picking the favourite.

review_title: Good job until corporate screws you
pros: - flexible hours - typically (not always) some really good supervisors and/or managers who care a lot about their fellow partners (employees) - fun environment to work it with a lot of opportunities to express yourself
cons: - if you aren’t lucky and have a good manager, you’re gonna have a bad time. I had the same (AMAZING) manager for 3 years, and when they left the company for an extended medical leave, ever other manager I worked with was absolutely horrendous. You either luck out with someone who cares about you, or you get a corporate drone. There is no in between. - corporate cuts hours like crazy. To the point that when you are working, you’re going to have a terrible experience because you’re so understaffed. This was especially prevalent following the initial Covid-19 lockdowns - often times if you are a hard worker, a LOT of other people’s slack gets put on you. Once you get good at the job, anyone who is lazy will put the work on you and it will be encouraged by managers who are terrified to actually fire people or give consequences - extremely hard to get time off or schedule your life outside work. You have to put requests for time off at least 3 weeks in advance, which is acceptable, except MOST MANAGERS DONT LOOK AT REQUESTS UNTIL THE WEEK THEY MAKE THE SCHEDULE. If you want a day off 6 months ahead, you have to hope you aren’t last to be seen on a highly Requested day, or else you’re gonna get denied 3 weeks before an event. I wanted time off for a 5 vacation in September, and put a request in in January, and it was denied 3 weeks before the vacation. - they advertise a lot of movement and growth opportunities, but a lot of the time they pass people up for outside hires, and they never last. I know many MANY people who have had this happen, for different positions: barista to supervisor, supervisor to store manager, managers to district managers. It seems like they always get passed up for an outside hire who never lasts because the job is so demanding - so many more. The job used to be fun but it’s gone so downhill in the last 3 or so years

review_title: If you’re looking for professionalism, keep looking
pros: The first day where I thought it was actually going to be everything it said it was going to be. It was all downhill from there
cons: - immature management - cliques - rude coworkers - permanent understaffing / high turnover - discrimination, racism, favoritism, harassment abound with no help to look to. partner resources and ethics and compliance are a joke. - disgusting environment - benefits aren’t that great- ASU doesn’t have very many online options for bachelor degrees, medical benefits are super pricey and come out of your check - tips suck - customers are rude and uneducated about the differences in stores / are not guided correctly throughout the store so they take it out on baristas with literally no control over anything because we’re drowning behind the bar - no support from anyone, DM is nonexistent - overcharging for very cheap ingredients / too much ice / etc things that are out of our control yet still get berated about on a daily basis by customers - lack of steady inventory, always running out of everything - lack of cleanliness / food safety across the board: bathrooms are never cleaned on time, sandwiches aren’t thrown out on time, sanitizer isn’t changed often enough, bug infestations, etc. - lack of training - low pay - low morale I could go on but I’ll spend my time looking for a better job instead… I’ve worked probably 8 different positions throughout various industries and this has been the worst experience of my “professional” career.

pros: This can be a great job to have because you can get benefits for working 20 hours a week and the benefits aren't half bad. If you have a great store manager it can make a world of a difference. I had a great SM, then someone new took over their store because they transferred to open a new store and this new SM was awful. We went from one of the fastest and highest earning stores in the area to one of the slowest and regulars who had came every day stopped coming because of the lack of efficiency.
cons: The fact that the customer is always right is ridiculous. Plenty of customers came and went in the store I worked at where we made their drinks exactly as they asked for and then claimed we made it wrong. We even had a customer who would say their drink was made wrong if the wrong person made it and another would make it the EXACT same way and say it was fine. These customers are exploiting the company and furthering the horrendous behavior people have towards those who work in customer service. These were not once in awhile instances, but EVERY. SINGLE. TIME, and each time, we had to "make it right" and give them exactly what they wanted. Also, just like any other major company, the top makes these ideas and new things that are just not realistic or feasible. They have never actually worked behind a counter and watching them try to navigate that part of the job on site was always a spectacle.

cons: This company is chaotic! You will end up picking up the slack when others do not do their part. There is little accountability. You will bust your butt for little to no recognition or compensation. I was working with the company for over three years and was still making under $11 an hour which is pathetic. They cut hours many times without communication with us or an apology even, which you would expect when people rely on their job for money to pay for things like food and rent. They always want the “connection” score to go up but how can they expect that when we are scheduled with only 2 people because we don’t “earn” more labor hours? Turnover is very high and the standards, policies, are always changing so no one is on the same page. Communication comes from many places so it is overwhelming and unclear. We are also always out of product yet they continue to open more stores when experiencing outages so it exasperates the problem.  I constantly bite my tongue and suppress communicating about issues because upper management does not support or seem to care about them when I do. I choose to just try and not let it affect me working there. When I have tried and spoken up about things change does not occur and it seems to only cause more stress for myself. Chaos. Also too much Alicia Keys for me personally. :p

review_title: Good Starter and benefits; Prioritize yourself
pros:
This job offers a lot of nice benefits and free counseling without having the healthcare plan. They will pay for tuition at a university in Arizona (I think) and they often have food that "goes bad" that they will toss (but say they give to homeless shelters) which you can then take and toss in the freezer if you are low on food/don't wanna cook.
They have a mental health partnership that offers really helpful tools and counselors who can give you a lot good advice and help.
Some regulars are very kind and even give gifts if they get to know you. 
Definitely need to have a good support group and love for your own worth because they will test you. There is leniency in the beginning though with "training" so good luck
cons:
The company does not prioritize you or your health and well-being. You must fight for yourself if you don't want to burn out and get reprimanded for needing time to recoup from a stressful work environment. Do not offer full-time if you cannot handle the workload. It is taxing on you after a while. 
There will be coworkers and managers who also do not care if you disappeared, so thick skin is a must.
Some regulars will curse at you because you don't know their order. It is what it is.
Main priority is to limit the number of average wait time for the company which is what they actually care about.
This job can break you if you aren't ready to give it your all.
They also hate unions but won't market it like they do

pros: The benefits like paying for school and health insurance is awesome. They pay for an online bachelor's degree with Arizona State University. Definitely worth it for that alone. It has saved me so much money.
cons: I have worked at 3 different stores, two in California and 1 in Tennessee. Like all customer service, a bad manager can make or break your work experience. Not all managers are created equal and I definitely had a terrible one, but the other two were great! It is customer service so it can be draining for sure, but you definitely bond with your coworkers through all the chaos that can be Starbucks.

cons: Inconsistent management - I had nine managers in four years and not a singular one actually hired in time for holidays, could not get scheduling or staffing done correctly even with numbers showing we needed more staff Work life balance is nonexistent - people will call you on vacation to cover them, managers will threaten your hours to get you to come in on your day off Favoritism - managers and supervisors are inconsistent with rules if you’re not a “friend” and you will get passed up for promotions if you aren’t a doormat Sick time - you have it but can only use it if you call out and find coverage. If you call the day before and you’re sick, it’s not usable. You also can’t use it if you’ve stayed for more than half the day. Culture - Starbucks has a reputation as being great for being a misfit. Unfortunately, some of those hired are bigger hinderances than helps. This includes the guy who came to work everyday but had to practice his chords for thirty minutes so he could be “ready” to work. This includes people who would swear at customers, didn’t want to wash their hands, didn’t want to follow standards, but were friendly with general managers and allowed to stay after “coaching”. I also noticed that applicants of color with good references and previous experience were passed up for 15 year old white kids who’d quit in two weeks because the applicants were not “the right fit”.

review_title: It's alright (but not all the time)
pros: Tips Co-workers (unless shortstaffed in which case they can hire literally anyone) Free drinks and 1 sandwich, 1 pastry on shift + 50% off food on shift, 30% off everything off-shift Free counselling for a few sessions if needed Loans for securing a house deposit Opportunity for apprenticeships into team leaders and managers through the company Perks At Work discounts and point system across various retailers
cons: Upper management (district managers and above) have NO clue what it's like to be on the floor. They have unrealistic expectations, are so out of touch and impose changes onto the store structure without taking our opinions into account. Even my manager's. These changes only place strain onto our workload and relationships. When it's busy, it's horrific. The customers at every single Starbucks I've been to have been entitled, rude and condescending especially on weekends. So if you want to work here, you'll have to get thick skin quick. Be ready to be compared to other stores and be told that you should do xyz because the other store they go to also does xyz. Maybe our store is just neglected, but our equipment is so old and breaking down on an almost daily basis. It adds so much unnecessary stress and is what made me step down from being a supervisor. I'm talking sticker machines (so we never know who ordered what), display fridge (having to move out all food to back fridges so it doesn't spoil is never fun), both coffee machines, water filtration system, all of it. Maintenance is useless a lot of the time and there are long wait times despite priority ranking system. We are asked to cut labour despite us already struggling as we are, and our store being particularly difficult due to high volume of Uber/Deliveroo/Just Eat orders and similar ratio of food to drinks per order, and it makes working there so stressful. You can be asked to cover shifts in nearby stores which nobody ever likes doing. We rarely get any positive feedback from higher-ups, only criticism, which is incredibly demoralising. There are often shortages of everything, and there's insufficient planning for promos in terms of stock. I'm sure there's so much more I'm forgetting.

review_title: Used to be known for taking care of their people
pros: Decent benefits for an hourly job, fun fast-paced work environment so it's hard to get bored, great coworkers depending on your store.
cons: Pay is about $3 per hour less than other similar jobs in this area, training does not effectively prepare new hires for work, stores are always understaffed and no one gets as many hours as they agreed to upon hiring which is detrimental to survival, upper management is incredibly disconnected from the daily work of partners especially in high-traffic stores. Partners are somehow expected to make meaningful connections with customers while also making sure no one is waiting for their order in the drive-thru for more than 30 seconds. People get reprimanded for taking too long to send people on their way, but they also get reprimanded for not conversing with the customers while they wait. The job itself is far more physically demanding than most people expect, not to mention the mental toll of working with the uncaffeinated public. Worst of all would be the thinly veiled union-busting going on lately.

pros: The regular customers and co-workers are great to work with.
cons: Starbucks exploits workers. They never recognize good work except by pushing employees to work harder. They cut employee hours regularly until every person working at the store is doing 3 or 4 jobs at once. If you're assigned to the till, you're also in charge of brewing coffee every 10 minutes, pouring coffee and mixing in sugar/milk, making tea, collecting pastries, and cooking food. The stores are all constantly slammed, especially with how many people mobile order huge lists of drinks and food, yet employees are told that Starbucks isn't making enough money to be able to budget enough hours to run the store properly. So the workers suffer while the managers go on vacations constantly.

The location I trained at did not have a drive-through, for example, and even though I told the shift manager this, she insisted I use the headset despite me telling her I had literally never touched one before nor seen any guides on using it. Areas that were visible to customers were always spotless but anything beyond that was grimy or dusty and the back area was full of flies.

The time we need to use to manage and grow the business is cut and we are expected to work as a barista. It is just a way to avoid paying another partner, since as salary partners we are expected to complete all our work regardless.

review_title: Experience Varies from Starbucks to Starbucks
pros: Definitely have been missing the free drinks. I loved being creative and inventing new drinks! Personally I missed out on the 401K match and free education, but take advantage if you haven't already.
cons: I think it really varies to each Starbucks. Pay and tips were fairly low, but good for a first job experience. Overall the manager was kind and understanding. They took a lot of responsibility and worked to keep the business running. Some employees were more interested in drama and were extremely unprofessional. A lot of work was delegated because some leads didn't want to do that specific task. Tasks were based on favorability, not skill. So... if they didn't like you, unfortunately you're stuck cleaning bathrooms or scrubbing the pipes underneath the sink.

review_title: Lots to say about Starbucks, but..
pros:
Free drinks, mostly relaxed atmosphere, bonding with coworkers, and getting to know and try to accommodate the people in the community are the real highlights of the job. Personally I believe Spotify is a bad company but free premium was a compromise I was willing to make. You do you though. The free Headspace subscription was actually great as well. 
I will say the insurance is very good for what it is and though I had to jump through many hoops I was able to take an extended medical leave during a mental health crisis last year and keep my job thanks to my Starbucks insurance and Sedgewick, the claims company they use.
cons:
Of course there are strange people at every job. If you have the tools you need you'll be able to handle it. 
However, the company is kind of nefarious tbh. Can be extremely stressful depending on your store's location, district, management, scheduling. Recently many problems with people not getting the hours they need to survive . Scheduling can be very inconsistent and it makes it hard to plan. 
Pay is still not really enough for most people unless it's a just part-time extra job for you. Not to mention the blatant union-busting. I've seen enough not to recommend putting your heart in long-term.
oh and Lyra is trash. contact your health department for therapy

review_title: Modern Day Slavery - Only work here if its the LAST OPTION on Earth....
pros: Free coffee/food, Pay is alright, benefits are good (if they will schedule you enough hours to qualify for them)..... It will give you really good motivation to find a different job :)
cons: I came into this position very excited, what could be better than making coffee for people all day? This job completely changed my view of Starbucks. As a very very regular customer, I never knew the things going on behind the scenes. The biggest issue with Starbucks?? STAFFING!!! They severely understaff every store. I am in multiple groups with other SBUX workers, and it's the same across the board. They purposefully understaff these stores to "cut down on labor costs" except its impacting the customers in the worst way. A 45 minute wait for drinks is absolutely ridiculous, and the customers that yell at you about it are actually right for once. With our current scheduling, only one person can be on espresso bar handling Cafe orders, mobile orders, delivery orders, drive through orders.... The store managers will put you in awful positions, they don't schedule who you need to run a good shift. They don't allow enough time to clean stores (how are we supposed to close an entire cafe in 30 minutes??), which leads to SO many things being left dirty, which is so wrong to me. They value money WAY more than the "customer experience" that they preach so hard. Oh and it's not that people don't WANT to work. My whole store is begging for more hours, many including me have open availability. I asked for 40 hrs upon hiring, no one said anything to me when I mentioned this. I get 22 hours av.... absolute joke. Very saddened that this has been my experience with the company so far. Starbucks, do better.

pros: People were great to work with most of the time, like any job some people will be more pleasant that others. The insurance coverage was very good

I was very vocal about how I supported unions and when I gave 2 weeks notice that i wasn't able to be at a couple of shifts and couldn't find coverage they counted them as no call no shows, even though I did call the day of and gave notice. I was told on the first day that I wasn't there that this action would put me on suspension, but when I came back I was taken off all the schedules and my work profile was remotely deleted from my phone. After a couple of days of trying to talk to my former manager face to face I was told that Starbucks, "doesn't do suspensions" and that I must have misheard her on the phone, even though my whole family heard the call and heard suspension, so from my point of view I was told i was on suspension for a smaller offense than some of my anti-union coworkers then I was fired without being told I was fired until I happened to come in to talk with my manager a couple days later.

review_title: The people you work with will make or break it
job_title: Barista/Shift Supervisor in Lakewood Ranch, FL
pros: > The benefits are amazing. But they are not completely paid for and that can be a negative depending on the medical coverage that you need. > I like a good challenge. Especially at peaks. If you like to see how many things you can keep track of at once it can be fun. Especially when you're on point. > You get free coffee. It's amazing as a pick-me-up whenever you need it but you will almost certainly get addicted if you are not already. (This is a great job for someone who loves Starbucks already and needs a job) > Can be a lot of fun to crush it at high volumes with cool people. > When it's slow and you get to hangout with your coworkers and possibly make absurd drink combinations. At these slow times its also great to have more meaningful conversations with customers (especially regulars). > I had a blast when I was in training and I had a blast training people.
cons: > I don't think the pay is compensatory for the work and workload that some employees are required to take on. I did not have it as bad as some, but some days the demand is nonstop and it can really wipe you out having to go 100mph for 8 hours. Sometimes you even are expected to skip breaks and deal with it. > Being understaffed, which was like 60% of the time, is soul crushing. It has the potential to get so bad that there is literally I mob of people just standing in the lobby, switching between staring at their phones to staring at you, just waiting for their order to get finished. It can feel like you are a rat in a cruel experiment. In these cases it helps just to laugh because there is, in the case of being understaffed, nothing that you could have done to avoid this. > You are going to get some real jerks (censored on my description here). They are worse in the periods of time when you're already peaked out and stressing. God bless you if you can talk to them with finesse still at this point. They can really put a damper on what can otherwise be a good time. But it's a good feeling to be able to handle these people in the heat of the moment. > If you want to move up, get ready for politics. Each step up seems to bring more and more so pucker up because thats going to take some brown nosing. > The schedules are whatever your manager wants them to be and you are at their mercy so best of luck with that. Note that more tenured employees should get better schedules or have their pick of it.

The best part is working in a great team environment with great people who are passionate about their jobs. - And of course there are a lot of good perks with the job such as discount cards (for more than just Starbucks), free beverages, partner competitions, regular pay rise’s & opportunities to excel. pros:
- Amazing coworkers, lots of diversity, laughs, and positivity (in spite of even the most difficult shifts)
-Actual "Coffee Crafting" responsibilities are intensely fun and interesting, lots of food-science knowledge to be gained - but as far as I've seen only Reserve Baristas like myself felt like "real" baristas with genuine, deep rooted coffee knowledge
- Documentation of all employee hours/availability, pay, and benefits changes: easy to comprehend paperwork and decent employee protections
- Benefit/Educational opportunities (not including the "free" Spotify that you actually pay for every month)
- Kind, fun regulars and consistent social interaction with all walks of life
cons: Overworked, underpaid, unappreciated, and ignored by every form of management - dehumanized and seen only as a small fish in the biggest of ponds: an asset, not a human. Management will not do much to go out of their way to cover any shifts, even if someone were to get into a car crash or ended up in the hospital, someone who is gravely injured would be (as I witnessed multiple times) expected to find coverage through a fellow employee. Consequences for showing up even 5 minutes late, no matter the weather or circumstance. Lack of growth opportunities that don't force one to agree to the absolute greying-and-blurring of lines dissecting one's personal life vice work life. No consistency to raises, empty promises. A company that truly cares more about the smile you provide a customer than the genuineness of the smile itself: customer first, always and forever.

review_title: Just do it for the benefits
pros: - Great relationships - Coffee’s pretty good - First bachelor’s through ASU - Health coverage
cons: - work 24/7. With a team of 30 baristas, you’re constantly bombarded with calls/text messages. Even on the store manager’s group chat, managers text after hours at 10 or 11pm. Ridiculous. - Low pay for the amount of hours put in weekly - Tremendous amount of physical work, including getting on your knees to constantly clean the store. All my clothes are stained with bleach spots - If you want to grow after being a store manager, you’re made to jump through hoops to not even get called for an interview. - My DM was the last person you’d want as a leader. Uneducated, rude, overall ignorant of how business works. - At the end of the day, the ONLY thing that matters is how well you speak to an audience and how well you get along with your higher ups. Those are the ones being rewarded, not the ones delivering solid results.

They kept your tips and allegedly split them evenly between all staff at the end of the month and you'd have to trust it was correct, but if the till was off at the end of the day it came out of employees combined tips. Staff were not allowed a voice and punished for communicating.

pros:
- Regular Pay Increases
- Flexible Hours
- Huge variety of benefits from free Spotify, Headspace, and 22 therapy sessions with Lyra, etc. 
- 100% Tuition Reimbursement with ASU for partners that work over 20 hours weekly.
- Regular and Consistent Seasonal Training.
- Free food, drink, and coffee bean mark out weekly.
- 5% Match indefinitely on IRA and Roth IRA accounts with Fidelity.
- 7 Restricted Starbucks Stock Units that release over two years when setting up IRA.
cons:
- Popularity contest for who gets promoted within store front positions. 
- Each store is ran differently according to what the manager values. 
- Some locations are very stressful and fast paced. 
- Rude and entitled customers
- You’re timed on every position within the store. 
- Standing long hours, for all of your shift. 
- Lunch breaks are 30mins long and only given if you work a 6+ hour day. Shifts longer than 3 hours are given a 10 minute long break.
- Constant animosity from different day parts to one another: Openers vs Closers
- Must be able to lift heavy items: like four gallons of milk at a time, 14 liters of water, 10lbs of soaking wet coffee grounds, etc.
- High risk of being cut, burned, or injured.

pros: Decent pay, good camaraderie with coworkers. Store manager was great, but that depends entirely on the character of the individual- not the company.
cons: No accountability for corporate actions- I had to fight tooth-and-nail to have a supervisor removed for sexually harassing multiple staff members. In the end, they considered him violating tobacco-use policies (vaping in the store) to be the "official" reason for his termination. Corporate ignores complaints and concerns, and responds to misconduct by shuffling "problem" managers from one store to another, rather than addressing the misconduct. I had to take a disability leave due to health issues, followed by a 5-month unpaid "accommodation" leave. While on leave, the district manager was replaced by a store manager with countless complaints of bullying and intimidation. On my return-to-work date - the same day I handed over my doctor's note for accommodations, basically just requesting to not be over-worked - they immediately fired me for "attendance policy violations" from 7 months prior. Upper management terrorizes staff and threatens to cut hours as means of discouraging union organization.

pros: Good benefits like health insurance, free tuition for an online university, the partner fund, and a long list of lots of other benefits. Free coffee, drinks, food and discounts at any starbucks location was amazing, I never had to worry about where to get my next meal. Tips were good sometimes.
cons: Insane expectations for timeliness and customer service. It always felt like we were understaffed or had just barely enough people to run the store even though so many baristas complained about not having enough hours. One or two people making the all of the drinks for drive through, dine in, and mobile would cause us to constantly be behind on orders, and of course this would lead to angry and impatient customers blaming us. Additionally, most baristas would get scheduled just under 6 hours so we would only get 15 min breaks instead 30 minute lunch (as would be legally required). I was often working on an empty stomach because as per the policy at the time, I also would have to order and wait for my food like a customer would, which would take at least 10 minutes.

review_title: Overall I have enjoyed my time
pros: I have had some of the best opportunities that I could ask for working at Starbucks. Connecting with customers while making drinks for people has been incredibly fun! It is fast-paced and challenging at times, but it also tests your ability to multitask and problem-solve. As for my experience, I have had managers that are pretty open to working with my schedule outside of work
cons: It can be very very busy sometimes. For some people, it's not much of an issue. But many people can't handle the chaos that can ensue during a very busy peak. Starbucks emphasizes connecting with customers, so if you're not a people person, this job really isn't for you. There is also the possibility that you will be called in on your day off - you don't have to go in, but people are always calling off.

review_title: Once better than the alternatives, now in decline
pros: Compared to other companies in the industry, the benefits are a big plus. While ASU is a bit of a joke, a diploma is a diploma, and this makes one attainable.
cons:
In order to get any sort of meaningful pay raise, you need to move into management, and those positions are a nightmare. Starbucks provides next to no leeway for availability once you rise above the level of barista, and due to the ongoing staffing shortages, you're likely to be called in all the time.
Speaking of, the allotment of labor hours is handled by an algorithm which leaves no wiggle room. I had to consistently pile all my barista's shifts to meet demand for peak business hours, which left the rest of the day playing catchup. During my last six months especially, I was routinely staying 20-60 minutes past the end of my shift, regardless of when my shift started.

job_title: Barista, Shift Supervisor in Modesto, CA
pros: I loved my time with Starbucks! I have worked at 3 stoors and always moved stoors for positive reasons. Typically you will work with energetic hard-working people. Lots of customers are amazing people with great life stories, some will regulars will even end up giving you gifts for holidays. Flexible hours, all the caffeine could need during a work day, a fast passed environment, and lots of practice in communicating with people. If you are shy or timid when in conversations with people and wish you weren't then I highly recommend getting a job with Starbucks the training they have and the number of connections you make with people on a daily basis will empower you with new confidence in talking with people. It happened to me and I have watched it happen with many partners over the years that I was with Starbucks. My managers have always been greater and even planned events for their stoors partners to get together and celebrate each other. Starbucks is for the most part very good about promoting capable managers with strong people skills. So if you want to work at a place where you can move up and are genuine, even if you don't have the skills, they will develop a plan for your success.
cons: Your job is people, yes you make drinks and serve some food but don't be confused your job is to make people, even if just for the moment that they are with you, happier than they were before they got to you. (Realy this isn't a con but in my experience, people who did not enjoy their time working at Starbucks really didn't like dealing with or helping people.)

review_title: Stressful job, but nice customers and dogs in the drive-thru make it bearable
pros: Free Spotify, Headspace, and therapy app usage, benefits, free tuition at a specific online college, free drink and food during your shift, tips, flexible schedule, potential growth, plenty of hours because they're usually understaffed, most of the co-workers are super nice and make it worth working there. I stayed at Starbucks longer than I wanted to because my fellow "partners" made it worth it.
cons: Constantly understaffed, so you have to do the job of 3 while also dealing with impatient customers. Rude customers, customers with specific orders who are rude about it, people shoving their phone in your face to show you a tiktok drink, having to do mobile orders, uber eats, and cold bar all at once sometimes, overworked and underpaid, fellow "partners" always late so you have to stay much later, some of the higher-up managers don't seem to care that you're overworked, having to take orders outside in super hot or freezing cold climates, sore feet from standing the whole shift, sore shoulders (from the apron always tugging on them), having to withstand a lot of mental abuse from customers who will take their anger out on you even if you only said "hi" to them in a polite manner

pros: College degree benefit (only if you don’t already have a bachelors though)
cons: Overworked and underpaid for the amount of stress they put you under.

pros: Starbucks offers great benefits as well as opportunity to grow. Some of my coworkers took advantage of their college program achievement program, allowing them to gain a bachelors degree while working at the company part time. Working part time allows you to receive some good health benefits as well. The hours are very flexible. I loved the team I worked with. They place an emphasis on training and set aside time to continually check in with you. Overall, this is a great job especially if you are looking for career advancement within the company. Its also a great job if you just want to work seasonally.
cons: If you don't set boundaries you could end up working a lot more than you planned. Just make sure to set aside days that you want off when making your availability because it is really easy to overwork yourself. Staffing shortages can also become a problem. There were a number of times when I would close the store and we wouldn't get out for an hour because there was so much to do. It can be extremely stressful working when there aren't enough people on the floor.
